doc.after: Mycena aurantiomarginata is generally recognizable in the field by its olive-brown to orangish cap, bright orange gill edges, and yellowish hairs at the base of the stipe. M.Â elegans is similar in appearance to M.Â aurantiomarginata, and some have considered them synonymous.[20] M.Â elegans is larger, with a cap diameter up to 3.5Â cm (1.4Â in) and stipe length up to 12Â cm (4.7Â in), darker, and has pale greenish-yellow colors on the gill edges and stipes that stain dull reddish-brown in age.[21] M.Â leaiana is readily distinguished from M.Â aurantiomarginata by the bright orange color of its fruit bodies, its clustered growth on rotting wood, and the presence of a gelatinous layer on its stipe.[22] M.Â strobilinoides closely resembles M.Â aurantiomarginata in shape, size, spore morphology, and the presence of hairs at the stipe base. It has a cap color that ranges from scarlet to yellow, and features scarlet edges on widely spaced, pale pinkish-orange to yellow gills.[23]
